explanation:
The correct calculation requires dividing 330 ml by 1000 (since 1 litre = 1000 ml):  
330 ÷ 1000 = 0.33 litres.  

The student likely calculated 330 ÷ 100 = 3.3 litres.  

The error stems from using a divisor of 100 instead of 1000 when converting millilitres to litres. This indicates a misunderstanding of the relationship between metric units, specifically conflating the conversion factor for centi- (100) with milli- (1000).  

The misconception directly caused the student to reduce the unit size by two decimal places (÷100) rather than three (÷1000). This differs from the "10ml in a litre" misconception (which would yield 33 litres) and aligns precisely with "divided by 100 rather than 1000," as no decimal-point misplacement (e.g., shifting two places instead of three) needs to be inferred.
